tool.name: pbmm2
tool.description: map PacBio reads to a reference genome.
tool.command:
## set up files #set reads_fn = 'reads.' + $reads.ext ln -s '$reads' '$reads_fn' &&
#if $reference_source.reference_source_selector == 'history': #set ref_fn = 'reference.fa' ln -f -s '$reference_source.ref_file' '$ref_fn' && #else: #set ref_fn = $reference_source.ref_file.fields.path #end if
## run pbmm2 pbmm2 align -j \${GALAXY_SLOTS:-4} '$reads_fn' '$ref_fn' out.aligned.bam --sort

param.name: reference_source_selector
param.label: Will you select a reference genome from your history or use a built-in index?
param.option: Use a genome from history and build index

validator.message: A built-in reference genome is not available for the build associated with the selected input file

param.name: ref_file
param.label: Use the following dataset as the reference sequence
param.help: You can upload a FASTA sequence to the history and use it as reference

param.name: reads
param.label: reads
param.help: PacBio reads in BAM or [gzipped] fasta or fastq format.

tool.help:
**What it does**
A minimap2 wrapper for PacBio data: native PacBio data in ⇨ native PacBio BAM out.
--------------
pbmm2 is Pacific Biosciences’ wrapper for `minimap2 <https://github.com/lh3/minimap2>`__\ ’s C API. It supports native PacBio input. Output can be used directly for polishing using `pbgcpp <root?tool_id=pbgcpp>`__.
**Input**: PacBio reads in bam or [gzipped] fasta or fastq format. **NOTE**: to use the output of pbmm2 for pbgcpp (GenomicConsensus), you have to provide PacBio CLR reads in bam format. You can use pbmm2 to align other types of PacBio reads in [gzipped] fasta or fastq format, but you can’t use the output for pbgcpp (GenomicConsensus).
**Output**: A **sorted** PacBio BAM file, suitable for use with `pbgcpp <root?tool_id=pbgcpp>`__ (previously known as GenomicConsensus).
